Stepping in as an artist who uses a couple different paper types for watercolors and guoache: maybe instead of watercolor, which is much softer and VERY absorbant, try smooth finish cold press bristol paper? I know when I use it for watercolor mixed media paintings, I do have to pre-soak it like watercolor paper, BUT if you don’t pre-soak it, you might get a stronger image, as the negative print might sit more flush on it. And tape the edges down with painters tape.

It’s a bit like burning a silk screen for silk screen printing. The print needs to sit totally tight and flush on the prepped silk screen in order to get a super sharp image when exposed to UV light. The print also needs to be a SOLID black and white, no light passing through the black, so bumping up the contrast should help.

Yeah, I know, three years later. ^^

For coating your paper you might consider using an anhydrous-solvent medium, like for full anhydrous-solvent-based industrial inks. It will allow your DNBP to be supported evenly in the solution by the medium and therefore having much less marked brush marks. Also, annoying because it’s tricky to make, you’d probably need to increase your DNBP concentration in the ink. Going fully anhydrous has the vantage to leave your DNBP stable but also, not bending your paper so much (paper bending and retraction is a massive problem with water-solvent based inks in printmaking).

Other solution as to avoid a anhydrous-solvent solution (as they’re generally fairly more toxic) is to work, as for screen printing, with an emulsion between castor oil, water, and a siccative agent. Basically a said water-based print screen ink or a transparent acrylic medium should be just fine. With the screen print one though you can have a better control on how you coat your image as you can print an empty frame or alternatively, print your image itself. With the gesso just work like you did. There are transfer gesso/mediums that are designed to avoid bending.

Also, sunlight is a shit light source for any kind of exposure. Work with arc lamps and measure your time.

For the photographic paper.... what you made was the equivalent of VERY early 1800s photographic paper.... silver nitrate solution brushed onto paper. Its primary weakness was lack of (visual) saturation, because the blacks didn't get very dark, due to a lack of silver salt (chloride and/or iodide and/or bromide) crystals.

The solution is to make an emulsion. Modern day emulsions are made from "hard" (acid-dissolved, high melting temp) gelatin, into which the photosensitive chemicals are mixed, and layered on (in, of course, complete darkness, because silver salts are so light-sensitive).

In the 1800s, such emulsions were made with egg white, to make what was called "albumen prints"

Albumen paper is made by carefully breaking bird eggs (don't break the yolks), and pouring off the clear liquid to separate container use while using a coarse barrier to keep the yolks in the original container (even a coffee cup and a finger held to create a small opening for the white to pour out through can work in a pinch.)

Paper would be hand-coated, by paint brush) with a silver-salt-in-egg-white mixture, and each sheet hung by the corner in a dark room to dry using a paperclip or laundry clothes pin. After this layer dried, the paper would be unevenly coated, with a diagonal gradient away from the top corner towards the bottom corner. The solution is to coat the paper a 2nd time, and hang from the opposite corner.

My understanding is that the egg white emulsion smells TERRIBLE while it's drying (So, you might want to do this outside on a length of twine hung in a garage or a shed). You still want to do it inside a building, because you don't want dust getting into your egg white, and you don't want the wind whipping it around. Putting a fan in the room for GENTLE air circulation isn't a problem. Room should be reasonably dust-free. Putting a furnace-filter capable of trapping dust (not just lint) on the intake side of a box fan works well as a dust-remover.

If you have ever seen any black and white print on albumen paper with your own eyes, the quality is absolutely startling, even those which were created during the 1860's, due to the barely visible thickness of the albumen emulsion. These were all handmade using zero automation, as nobody had come up with a way to quickly dry albumen paper in a horizontal position, and hanging uses so much less space (vertical orientation), and requires far less material (2 nails plus length of twine plus clothes pins, vs tables

I would fill a tray with the DNBP in Acetone and dip the whole sheet of paper in it, rather than trying to brush it on evenly. Then pull it out and let it dry.

You might also just get better results from coating a sheet of clear plastic or glass in the stuff. Paper is always going to have irregularities and absorption weirdnesses that are going to interfere with getting a nice, clean image out of it. You might have better luck coating a sheet of glass and then covering it with with some sort of fixing clear coat (non-UV blocking, of course) to keep it from getting scraped or rubbed off.

I'm not totally sure of this, but I think that these problems you had with paper are probably the same reasons for why early photographic processes were done on glass or metal plates rather than paper or parchment. Aside from just holding up better to all the different chemical processing they had to go through, I'm pretty sure it was also just because it was an easier way to get an even, flat surface and coating.

I don't think that many more nitrated forms are possible. The para position of the benzene will be nitrated first while it's in the ice bath because the ortho ones are sterically hindered and thus nitration in those positions is kinetically unfavored. Once you nitrate the ortho position of the benzene the reaction will stop there because the tri-nitrated form  won't form in those conditions. Plus even if you nitrate the ortho position first (this will happen to some extent) the pyridine ring will be "locked" facing in the other direction, definitely covering the other ortho position, thus making the para position even more reactive. So, with those two effects together, I think that the amount of ortho-ortho product will be negligible. The pyridine ring is downright impossible to nitrate with normal lab reagents.

@NileRed if the photo emulsion you made would be stable then perhaps trying to use a latex or acrylic binder (sold in art supply stores) would work? Your results look not dissimilar to Liquid Light, which is a commercially available black and white photo emulsion paint, that you develop using standard photo darkroom chemicals. I also suggest looking into anthotypes, where plants are used to create photographic emulsions, as they could pose similar issues in terms of getting a good coating on the paper.
Make sure to use unbleached paper, do multiple coats of your emulsion, use an airbrush if possible (assuming the particles won't clog the nozzle) and coat vertically, then horizontally as required to get a better result. I would guess you probably need about 5-10 coats, each thoroughly dried in between to get a good result. In addition I would use a darker transparency and make sure the blacks are really opaque, as required when exposing screen printing screens. The blacks on your negative look like they might be a little thin, a simple solution to this is to layer two identical negatives to increase the opacity, or to print negatives at a higher ink density.

I was hoping to make a print when I saw this title, thanks for trying exactly that!
I don't know if there would be any reactions with the DNPB, but I was thinking of using a method similar to a gelatin or albumen silver print. I wonder if the coating would be smoother if the DNBP was mixed into a photo grade gelatin or albumen and then floating the paper on top? The epoxy bears looked nice and smooth so hopefully the gelatin layer would work the same. The color change may have less permanence than the epoxy bears as well since it is relatively soft.
Another method I would try is gum dichromate. Still, this would call for gelatin sized paper. All it calls for is some gum arabic, ammonium or potassium dichromate and a pigment of choice; substituting the DNBP in this case. If this method works, it would actually result in a "permanent" image. The gum dichromate will harden according to the negative allowing the underexposed areas to be washed away. It could possibly be stored as a latent image in the dark and reveal the image in the sun without having to print the negative. As long as the dichromate and DNBP don't affect each other that is. Also, this may not solve the coating issues.
Third and easiest suggestion, try using a puddle pusher, I still like brush coating, but the puddle pusher is a godsend when I can't seem to get the coating right. I bought mine through Bostick and Sullivan.

I think this should be tested on different types of paper as well as with repeated cycles of heating-cooling-watering. It could be possible that the lignin and cellulose thermally expand at a different enough rates to cause gaps that the DNBP keyholes into. When cooled down it could have just enough grip to hold DNBP in place, but also create gaps that water can seep into. Once the water seeps in, vascular action could pop it back out, allowing the crystal to rearrange itself again. If this is true then DNBP treated paper would deteriorate at a different rate than untreated paper with excessive cycling.

Nile, I think in this case chemically the photochromic effect is different! It seems more likely that the pendant amine moieties in your epoxy hardener extracted the weak proton from the 'CH2 form', this would form an olefin 'conjugated bridge' giving you that blue color appearance. Then, when you shine light the olefin becomes excited and takes back the proton from the amine, giving you the starting material again.

Very VERY interesting!

One way to disprove this hypothesis would be to add your 2-(2 4-dinitrobenzyl)pyridine directly into the hardener, it should abstract the proton and give you a dark color.

You put the solid crust from your ether contaminated water into a waste container? Ether can form organic peroxides which are explosive. My suggest would have been to continually test it as you allowed it to evaporate for those organic peroxides (buy some test strips from Fisher or something). Quick and easy test that might prevent an explosion in your lab some day!

Boiling off ether has the same effect as allow it to dry, in concentrates any organic peroxide that may have formed! Again, test with peroxide test strips when possible (especially as your ether ages)!

Your colour wheel is wrong, and seems to be based on Newton's numerology-based spectrum. Human colour vision works through detection of light in the red, green, and blue spectrums of light, which means the complements of those colours are cyan, magenta, and yellow, respectively. Instead of "Roy G Biv" it's "Mr. Ygcb" (starting at the only nontrivial point on the wheel, magenta), or, if you want to include tertiary colours like orange, it's "Mr. Roy C.G. McAbv" (Magenta, rose, red, orange, yellow, chartreuse, green, mint, cyan, azure, blue, and violet).

Have you tried heating the bears in the dark after exposing them to sunlight? Considering that they went blue during polymerization, I would assume the NH-Form is stabilized by the surrounding polymer chains (Presumably via NH-Hydrogen Bonding, which doesn't occur in the CH2-Form). This would suggest the blue form is thermodynamically favored in the polymer matrix, so if you heat the yellow polymer bears, you're more likely to overcome the kinetic rotation barrier and allow the molecules to revert back into their blue form.
If this doesn't work, either the kinetic barrier is too high or the sunlight (or heat) exposure somehow compromised the stabilizing interaction between the NH-Form and the polymer chains permanently.

Very nice work as usual, the bear working in reverse was a total surprise! Some comments on the schemes. First, at 8:34 the first proton transfer gives compound 1 but it mistakenly gets reduced in the process, there should still be a double-bond to an oxygen (this can also be seen as the charges do not balance). Second, at 3:19 the pyridine is most likely in its protonated form in the acid mixture, the active extraction neutralizes the pyridinium, crashing out the product.

I've been working with aromatic nitro-compounds for a while, so i can give you some hints about color changes. Your compound is both acidic (CH2) and electrophilic (phenyl ring). It's acidity means, that it can undergo proton transfer in the absence of UV-light, but in the presence of base. Electrophility means, that it can add various nucleophiles to its's nitrated ring and form so-called sigma-Meisenheimer complexes. These complexes are actually strongly colored in deep-violet/purple/deep-blue range and degrades in highly basic solutions pretty fast. Your epoxy hardener contains a lot of amines, that can react with DNBP, forming these semi-stable complexes. The more you know!

The contrast is low on your prints because of the low concentration of pigment in the paper. Try doing multiple applications with drying cycles in between to deposit more pigment. Also, you could try to create an emulsion of the pigment in agar or gelatin and pour it over the  paper while it is glued to a piece of glass. You can also improve contrast by increasing the density (make the dark areas darker) of your negative in photoshop to prevent the light bleeding through and exposing the areas underneath. edit:  you could also try creating a nitrocellulose film impregnated with your pigment, or applying the pigment as an emulsion over a plastic sheet. Then when you expose the print, place it on a black surface to prevent backscatter from exposing the protected areas.
